Questions: What is the purpose of a pointer
Answers: "It allows you to store an address in memory"

Questions: What is an abstract data type
What is a queue
Answers: "A queue is a (FIFO) first in first out Data Structure"

Questions: What are the 2 functions of a queue
Answers: "enqueue - adding to the end
column3: dequeue - taking the first item in line"

Questions: What is a stack
Answers: A stack is a (LIFO) last in first out abstract data structure

Questions: What are the operations for a stack
Answers: "Push - Adding to the top of stack

Questions: What is an array
Answers: "A chunk of memory where items are stored back to back to back"

Questions: What is the primary advantage of a linked list over an array?
Answers: "Dynamic size"

Questions: How can you find the middle of a linked list in a single pass?
Answers: "Using two pointers technique
column3: one advancing two steps at a time (fast pointer)
column4: and the other one step at a time (slow pointer)."

Questions: What data structure would you use to implement a stack?
Answers: "Linked List or Array"

Questions: How do you reverse a linked list?
Answers: "Using iterative method or recursive method"

Questions: Which sorting algorithm has the best worst-case runtime?
Answers: "Merge sort and heapsort have O(n log n) worst-case runtime."

Questions: What is the main difference between a queue and a stack?
Answers: "Queue uses FIFO (First In First Out) and Stack uses LIFO (Last In First Out) principles."

Questions: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in a hash table?
Answers: "O(1) on average"

Questions: In tree traversal, which traversal visits the left subtree, then the root, then the right subtree?
Answers: "In-order traversal"

Questions: What data structure is used in a breadth-first search of a graph?
Answers: "Queue"

Questions: What is the primary use of a binary heap?
Answers: "As a priority queue"

Questions: How is a bubble sort algorithm implemented?
Answers: "By repeatedly swapping adjacent elements if they are in the wrong order."

Questions: What is the difference between a breadth-first search and a depth-first search?
Answers: "BFS explores all nodes at the present depth before moving to nodes at the next depth level
column3: while DFS explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking."

Questions: How does the quicksort algorithm work?
Answers: "It works by selecting a 'pivot' element and partitioning the other elements into two sub-arrays according to whether they are less than or greater than the pivot."

Questions: What is a balanced binary search tree?
Answers: "A binary search tree in which the depth of the two subtrees of every node never differs by more than 1."

Questions: Why are AVL trees important?
Answers: "They are self-balancing binary search trees
column3: ensuring O(log n) lookup and insertion times."

Questions: What is a hash collision and how is it handled?
Answers: "Occurs when two different keys hash to the same index in an array. It can be handled by chaining or open addressing."

Questions: How does Dijkstra's algorithm work?
Answers: "It finds the shortest path from a source vertex to all vertices in a weighted graph."

Questions: What is dynamic programming?
Answers: "A method for solving complex problems by breaking them down into simpler overlapping subproblems."

Questions: How can you determine if a linked list has a cycle using O(1) space?
Answers: "Using Floydâ€™s Cycle detection algorithm or two-pointer technique."

Questions: What is the difference between 'best', 'average', and 'worst' case time complexities?
Answers: "Best is the optimal case
column3: average is the expected case for random input
column4: and worst is the most inefficient case."

Questions: What is a trie used for?
Answers: "Storing a dynamic set of strings
column3: often used in search engines for predictive text."

Questions: What is a red-black tree?
Answers: "A type of self-balancing binary search tree."

Questions: How does the bellman-ford algorithm differ from Dijkstra's?
Answers: "Bellman-Ford works with graphs that have negative weight edges

Questions: What is a post-order tree traversal?
Answers: "Visits the left subtree

Questions: What is an adjacency matrix?
Answers: "A square matrix used to represent a finite graph
column3: indicating whether pairs of vertices are adjacent."

Questions: Why is the BFS algorithm ideal for finding the shortest path in an unweighted graph?
Answers: "Because it explores nodes layer by layer
column3: ensuring the shortest path is found before any longer paths."

Questions: What is a k-d tree used for?
Answers: "Partitioning space for nearest neighbor search algorithms in multidimensional space."

Questions: What is the time complexity of inserting an element into a binary search tree?
Answers: "O(log n) for a balanced tree but can be O(n) in the worst case for a skewed tree."

Questions: How are prefix sums useful in algorithms?
Answers: "They allow for constant-time look-up for the sum of elements in a range."

Questions: Which data structure can be used to find the highest element in a window of an array?
Answers: "A deque (double-ended queue) can efficiently track the maximum in a sliding window."
